Award.AwardTitle: Metamodel-Based Measurement, Control, and Optimization of Engineered Surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposed research provides funding for the development of efficient methods for measurement, control, and optimization of surfaces of manufactured products. The problem is challenging due to the complex nature of the profiles that exhibit nonstationarity and spatial correlation. Some type of surface measurements are time consuming making the online control infeasible, whereas some other types of surface measurements such as those based on images provide huge amounts of data making the estimation of the models computationally intractable. The need of modeling the manufacturing process variables for the purpose of optimization and adaptive control makes the problem even more challenging. These challenges are addressed in this project by proposing a novel easy-to-evaluate metamodel known as kernel-sum regression/interpolation and developing efficient engineering-driven sampling and modeling strategies.

If successful, the results of this research will help improve the quality and functionality of many manufactured products. The applications of the proposed research are not limited to engineered surfaces. The new metamodeling method can be applied in areas such as geology, environmental modeling, and astronomy. The new sampling strategies are also applicable in other areas such as in the large-scale computer and simulation experiments, which open its applications to a wide variety of problems in product design and manufacturing. The impacts of the research can also go beyond the manufacturing applications, such as improving the surface characteristics of solar cell for better energy conversion and improving the precise surface characteristics of hip/dental implants leading to better quality of life and the reduction of healthcare cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed modeling techniques that can be used for approximating complex response surfaces such as the surface of a Si wafer. These models are then used for developing cost-efficient measurements of surfaces, online process control, and optimization. The modeling method that we developed is very general and therefore, it found applications in diverse areas such as in approximating a complex probability distribution that quite often arises in Bayesian analysis. Novel experimental designs methods were also developed for gathering the data so as to improve the approximation of the model. Another contribution of the project was to integrate physics-based engineering models with measurement data to obtain better predictive models. Many of the ideas developed in the project were applied in solving real-life problems in industries. For examples, a sequential sensing strategy was developed for measuring Si wafer profiles; a Gaussian process-based method was developed for modeling Si wafer profiles; a Gaussian process-based method integrated with partial differential equations was developed for controlling a wire saw slicing process; modeling techniques were developed to detect defect patterns in steel rolled bars; a model that integrates analytical and finite element models was developed and applied in a micromachining process; and a process monitoring technique was developed that uses image data and applied to control steel rolled bar production.

 

The project outcomes were disseminated to the communities of interest through several journal publications and conference presentations. Five graduate students were partially supported by the grant. Four of them have graduated, of which two are working in major universities in U.S.A. and two in major industries in U.S.A.
